sn4.25:1.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato santike imā nibbejanīyā gāthāyo abhāsitvā tamhā ṭhānā apakkamma bhagavato avidūre pathaviyaṃ pallaṅkena nisīdi tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno kaṭṭhena bhūmiṃ vilikhanto.
sn4.25:1.1.eng: And then Māra the Wicked, after reciting these verses of disillusionment in the Buddha’s presence, left that place. He sat cross-legged on the ground not far from the Buddha, silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, scratching the ground with a stick.

sn4.25:1.2.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro yena māro pāpimā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsiṃsu:
sn4.25:1.2.eng: Then Māra’s daughters Craving, Malignancy, and Lust went up to Māra the Wicked, and addressed him in verse:
sn4.25:1.2.comm: Marcus Bingenheimer proposes emending arati to rati (“delight”), which is in line with the senses of the other names, and is found in certain sources (Studies in Āgama Literature 4.5). However, Sanskrit knows a malignant she-demon arāti, who must be chased away from children (Atharva Veda 118.1). Probably the Chinese translators normalized the term.

sn4.25:2.2.eng: What man are you upset about?
sn4.25:2.2.comm: Mara’s fascination with the Buddha seems more than professional. He was taking it personally.

sn4.25:2.3.eng: We’ll catch him with the snare of lust,

sn4.25:2.4.eng: like an elephant in the wild.
sn4.25:2.4.comm: Apparently cow elephants were used to trap wild bulls.

sn4.25:2.5.eng: We’ll tie him up and bring him back—

sn4.25:3.1.eng: “In this world he is the perfected one, the Holy One.

sn4.25:3.2.eng: He’s not easily seduced by lust.

sn4.25:3.3.eng: He has slipped free of Māra’s dominion;

sn4.25:3.4.comm: At this point, Māra has given up hope.

sn4.25:4.1.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn4.25:4.1.eng: Then Māra’s daughters Craving, Malignancy, and Lust went up to the Buddha, and said to him,

sn4.25:4.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā na manasākāsi, yathā taṃ anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto.
sn4.25:4.3.eng: But the Buddha ignored them, since he was freed with the supreme ending of attachments.
sn4.25:4.3.comm: In this idiom, the locative saṅkhaye acts as an instrumental or ablative of cause (saṅkhayā), that is, “with” or “due to” (rather than “in”) the ending of attachments. In similar contexts, khayā is usually ablative.

sn4.25:5.1.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
sn4.25:5.1.eng: Then Craving, Malignancy, and Lust withdrew to one side to think up a plan.

sn4.25:5.2.eng: “Men have a diverse spectrum of tastes.

sn4.25:5.3.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ ekasataṃ ekasataṃ kumārivaṇṇasataṃ abhinimmineyyāmā”ti.
sn4.25:5.3.eng: Why don’t we each manifest in the form of a hundred young maidens?”

sn4.25:5.4.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro ekasataṃ ekasataṃ kumārivaṇṇasataṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn4.25:5.4.eng: So that’s what they did. Then they went up to the Buddha and said to him,

sn4.25:5.6.pli: Tampi bhagavā na manasākāsi, yathā taṃ anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto.
sn4.25:5.6.eng: But the Buddha still ignored them, since he was freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

sn4.25:6.1.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
sn4.25:6.1.eng: Then Craving, Malignancy, and Lust withdrew to one side to think up a plan.

sn4.25:6.2.eng: “Men have a diverse spectrum of tastes.

sn4.25:6.3.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ ekasataṃ ekasataṃ avijātavaṇṇasataṃ abhinimmineyyāmā”ti.
sn4.25:6.3.eng: Why don’t we each manifest in the form of a hundred women who have never given birth?”

sn4.25:6.4.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro ekasataṃ ekasataṃ avijātavaṇṇasataṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn4.25:6.4.eng: So that’s what they did. Then they went up to the Buddha and said to him,

sn4.25:6.5.comm: They approach an unknown ascetic with an extravagant gesture of submission.

sn4.25:6.6.pli: Tampi bhagavā na manasākāsi, yathā taṃ anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto.
sn4.25:6.6.eng: But the Buddha still ignored them, since he was freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

sn4.25:7.2.pli: yannūna mayaṃ ekasataṃ ekasataṃ sakiṃ vijātavaṇṇasataṃ abhinimmineyyāmāti.

sn4.25:7.4.pli: sakiṃ vijātavaṇṇasataṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn4.25:7.4.eng: each manifested in the form of a hundred women who have given birth once …

sn4.25:7.6.pli: Tampi bhagavā na manasākāsi, yathā taṃ anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto.

sn4.25:8.2.pli: yannūna mayaṃ ekasataṃ ekasataṃ duvijātavaṇṇasataṃ abhinimmineyyāmāti.

sn4.25:8.4.eng: women who have given birth twice …

sn4.25:9.5.eng: But the Buddha still ignored them, since he was freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

sn4.25:9.6.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro ekamantaṃ apakkamma etadavocuṃ:
sn4.25:9.6.eng: Then Craving, Malignancy, and Lust withdrew to one side and said,

sn4.25:10.1.eng: ‘In this world he is the perfected one, the Holy One.

sn4.25:10.2.eng: He’s not easily seduced by lust.

sn4.25:10.3.eng: He has slipped free of Māra’s dominion;

sn4.25:11.1.pli: Yañhi mayaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā avītarāgaṃ iminā upakkamena upakkameyyāma hadayaṃ vāssa phaleyya, uṇhaṃ lohitaṃ vā mukhato uggaccheyya, ummādaṃ vā pāpuṇeyya cittakkhepaṃ vā.
sn4.25:11.1.eng: For if we had come on to any ascetic or brahmin like this who was not free of lust, his heart would explode, or he’d spew hot blood from his mouth, or he’d go mad or lose his mind.

sn4.25:11.2.pli: Seyyathā vā pana naḷo harito luto ussussati visussati milāyati;
sn4.25:11.2.eng: He’d dry up, wither away, and shrivel up like a green reed that was mowed down.”

sn4.25:12.1.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn4.25:12.1.eng: Then Māra’s daughters Craving, Malignancy, and Lust went up to the Buddha, and stood to one side.

sn4.25:12.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho taṇhā māradhītā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.25:12.2.eng: Māra’s daughter Craving addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn4.25:13.1.eng: “Are you swamped by sorrow <j>that you meditate in the forest?

sn4.25:13.2.eng: Have you lost a fortune, or do you long for one?

sn4.25:13.3.eng: Or perhaps you’ve committed <j>some crime in the village?

sn4.25:13.4.eng: Why don’t you get too close to people?

sn4.25:13.5.eng: And why does no-one get close to you?”

sn4.25:14.1.eng: “I’ve reached the goal, peace of heart.
sn4.25:14.1.comm: The Buddha’s responds more closely to the accusations than he did with her father. | This verse is quoted and discussed, and the Sutta cited by name as the “Maiden’s Questions” (kumāripañhā) at AN 10.26.

sn4.25:14.2.eng: Having conquered the army <j>of the likable and pleasant,

sn4.25:14.3.eng: alone, practicing absorption, I awakened to bliss.

sn4.25:14.4.eng: That’s why I don’t get too close to people,

sn4.25:14.5.eng: and no-one gets too close to me.”

sn4.25:15.1.pli: Atha kho arati māradhītā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.25:15.1.eng: Then Māra’s daughter Malignancy addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn4.25:16.1.eng: “How does a mendicant who has crossed five floods

sn4.25:16.2.eng: usually meditate here while crossing the sixth?
sn4.25:16.2.comm: Bodhi notes that the Sanskrit parallels here have present tense tarati for the Pali’s aorist atari. I translate assuming present tense. | Here the five floods must be the five senses, against which the Buddha has proven himself immune. Delight wants to know how to transcend the mind.

sn4.25:16.3.eng: How do they usually practice absorption <j>so that sensual perceptions

sn4.25:16.4.eng: are blocked out and don’t get hold of them?”

sn4.25:17.1.eng: “With tranquil body and mind well freed,

sn4.25:17.2.comm: The present participle asaṅkharāno is a unique form. The meaning is not entirely clear in this context. The commentary says it means not generating the three kinds of kamma that lead to rebirth.

sn4.25:17.3.eng: understanding the teaching, <j>they practice absorption without placing the mind;

sn4.25:17.4.pli: Na kuppati na sarati na thino.
sn4.25:17.4.eng: they’re not shaking or drifting or rigid.

sn4.25:18.1.eng: That’s how a mendicant who has crossed five floods

sn4.25:18.2.eng: usually meditates here while crossing the sixth.

sn4.25:18.3.eng: That’s how they usually practice absorption <j>so that sensual perceptions

sn4.25:18.4.eng: are blocked out and don’t get hold of them.”

sn4.25:19.1.pli: Atha kho ragā māradhītā bhagavato santike gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.25:19.1.eng: Then Māra’s daughter Lust addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn4.25:20.1.eng: “He lives with his community after cutting off craving,

sn4.25:20.2.eng: and many of the faithful will cross over for sure.

sn4.25:20.3.eng: Alas, this homeless one will snatch many men away,

sn4.25:20.4.eng: and lead them past the King of Death!”

sn4.25:21.2.eng: by means of the true teaching.

sn4.25:21.3.eng: When the Realized Ones are leading by the teaching,

sn4.25:21.4.eng: how could anyone who knows be jealous?”

sn4.25:22.1.pli: Atha kho taṇhā ca arati ca ragā ca māradhītaro yena māro pāpimā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
sn4.25:22.1.eng: Then Māra’s daughters Craving, Malignancy, and Lust went up to Māra the Wicked.

sn4.25:22.2.pli: Addasā kho māro pāpimā taṇhañca aratiñca ragañca māradhītaro dūratova āgacchantiyo.
sn4.25:22.2.eng: Māra the Wicked saw them coming off in the distance,

sn4.25:23.3.eng: You dig up a hill with your nails!

sn4.25:23.4.eng: You chew iron with your teeth!

sn4.25:24.1.eng: You seek a footing in the abyss, as it were,

sn4.25:24.2.eng: while lifting a rock with your head!

sn4.25:24.3.eng: After attacking a stump with your breast, as it were,

sn4.25:25.1.comm: Like the concluding verse of the previous Sutta, this must have been added by redactors.

sn4.25:25.3.eng: But the Teacher brushed them off right there,

sn4.25:25.4.eng: like the gale, a fallen tuft.

sn4.25:26.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with Māra are complete.

sn4.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn4.3:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn4.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn4.3:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

sn4.3:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā, bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato avidūre uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti, subhā ceva asubhā ca.
sn4.3:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, approached him, and while not far away, displayed a rainbow of bright colors, both beautiful and ugly.
sn4.3:1.4.comm: Māra appears like the godlings of Susīma’s assembly (SN 2.29:10.2). It is not easy to know what gods to trust.

sn4.3:1.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.3:1.5.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn4.3:2.2.eng: you’ve made forms beautiful and ugly.

sn4.3:3.4.comm: Paddhagū seems to be pa + addha + gū (or cara at SN 6.4:10.1), “one who travels in front”. They serve kings (Thag 13.1:1.2). The use of this term here suggests that they will not make Māra’s job easier for him by smoothing his path.

sn4.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
sn4.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn4.4:1.2.comm: The Buddha had come to Varanasi after his Awakening to teach the five ascetics (SN 56.11). This event is also preserved at Kd 1:13.1.1.

sn4.4:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn4.4:2.1.pli: “Mayhaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā yoniso sammappadhānā anuttarā vimutti anuppattā, anuttarā vimutti sacchikatā.
sn4.4:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I have attained and realized supreme freedom through rational application of mind and rational right effort.
sn4.4:2.1.comm: “Rational application of mind and rational right effort” is yoniso manasikārā yoniso sammappadhānā. The term yoniso (“by way of womb”) indicates that the cause and effect are aligned.

sn4.4:2.2.pli: Tumhepi, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikārā yoniso sammappadhānā anuttaraṃ vimuttiṃ anupāpuṇātha, anuttaraṃ vimuttiṃ sacchikarothā”ti.
sn4.4:2.2.eng: You too should attain and realize supreme freedom through rational application of mind and rational right effort.”

sn4.4:2.3.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.4:2.3.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.5:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
sn4.5:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn4.5:1.1.comm: This event is also told in the Vinaya (Kd 1:11.1.2). It is regarded as an archetypal event for all Buddhas, and hence is told in the context of the past Buddha Vipassī (DN 14:3.22.4).

sn4.5:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn4.5:2.1.pli: “Muttāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbapāsehi ye dibbā ye ca mānusā.
sn4.5:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I am freed from all snares, both human and heavenly.

sn4.5:2.2.pli: Tumhepi, bhikkhave, muttā sabbapāsehi ye dibbā ye ca mānusā.
sn4.5:2.2.eng: You are also freed from all snares, both human and heavenly.

sn4.5:2.3.pli: Caratha, bhikkhave, cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
sn4.5:2.3.eng: Wander forth, mendicants, for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

sn4.5:2.4.eng: Let not two go by one road.

sn4.5:2.5.pli: Desetha, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.
sn4.5:2.5.eng: Teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn4.5:2.6.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti.
sn4.5:2.6.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

sn4.5:2.7.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!

sn4.5:2.8.pli: Ahampi, bhikkhave, yena uruvelā senānigamo tenupasaṅkamissāmi dhammadesanāyā”ti.
sn4.5:2.8.eng: I will travel to the town of Senā in Uruvelā in order to teach the Dhamma.”
sn4.5:2.8.comm: Senā was where the Buddha attained Awakening, the pilgrimage site of Bodhgaya (MN 26:17.1). The events on his return to Uruvelā are told in the Vinaya (Kd 1:15.1.1). The Buddha encountered three Kassapa brothers who were fire-worshiping matted-hair ascetics, and converted them with their retinues.

sn4.5:2.9.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.5:2.9.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.5:3.3.eng: You’re bound by the great bond:

sn4.5:4.3.eng: I’m freed from the great bonds;

sn4.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn4.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn4.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn4.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

sn4.6:2.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo mahantaṃ sapparājavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
sn4.6:2.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, manifested in the form of a huge serpent king and approached him.

sn4.6:2.2.eng: Its body was like a huge canoe carved from a single tree.

sn4.6:2.4.eng: Its hood was like a large brewer’s sieve.

sn4.6:2.6.eng: Its eyes were like big bronze cups from Kosala.

sn4.6:2.8.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatā niccharanti;
sn4.6:2.8.eng: Its tongue flickered from its mouth like lightning flashes in a thunderstorm.

sn4.6:2.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kammāragaggariyā dhamamānāya saddo hoti;
sn4.6:2.10.eng: The sound of its breathing was like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.

sn4.6:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.6:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn4.6:5.1.eng: Though there are lots of creepy crawlies,

sn4.6:5.2.eng: and lots of flies and snakes,

sn4.6:5.4.eng: of a great sage in that empty hut.

sn4.6:6.1.eng: Though the firmament may split <j>and the earth may quake,

sn4.6:6.2.eng: and all creatures be stricken with fear;

sn4.6:6.3.eng: and even if an arrow’s aimed at their breast,

sn4.6:6.4.eng: the Buddhas take no shelter in attachments.”

sn4.6:7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.6:7.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn4.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn4.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bahudevarattiṃ abbhokāse caṅkamitvā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ pāde pakkhāletvā vihāraṃ pavisitvā
sn4.7:1.2.eng: He spent much of the night walking mindfully in the open. At the crack of dawn he washed his feet and entered his dwelling.

sn4.7:1.3.pli: dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasi karitvā.
sn4.7:1.3.eng: He laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

sn4.7:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.7:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.7:2.1.comm: Lacking substantive arguments, Māra picks on the Buddha for sleeping.

sn4.7:2.2.eng: You sleep like a loser—<j>what’s up with that?

sn4.7:2.3.eng: You sleep, thinking that the hut is empty.

sn4.7:2.4.eng: You sleep when the sun has come up—<j>what’s up with that?”

sn4.7:3.2.eng: the weaver, the clinger—<j>to track them anywhere.

sn4.7:3.3.eng: With the ending of all attachments <j>the awakened Buddha sleeps.

sn4.7:3.4.eng: What’s that got to do with you, Māra?”

sn4.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn4.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn4.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn4.8:1.3.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn4.8:2.3.eng: For attachments are a man’s delight;

sn4.8:2.4.pli: Na hi so nandati yo nirūpadhī”ti.

sn4.8:3.2.eng: Your cattle also bring you sorrow.

sn4.8:3.3.eng: For attachments are a man’s sorrow;

sn4.8:3.4.pli: Na hi so socati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
sn4.8:3.4.eng: without attachments there are no sorrows.”

sn4.8:4.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.8:4.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn4.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn4.9:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn4.9:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, the lifespan of humans is short.

sn4.9:2.2.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ.
sn4.9:2.2.eng: You must go to the next life. So you should do what is skillful, you should practice the spiritual life.

sn4.9:2.4.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ciraṃ jīvati, so vassasataṃ appaṃ vā bhiyyo”ti.
sn4.9:2.4.eng: A long life is a hundred years or a little more.”

sn4.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.9:3.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.9:4.2.eng: A true person wouldn’t scorn it.

sn4.9:4.4.eng: for Death has not come for you.”

sn4.9:5.2.eng: and a true person scorns it.

sn4.9:5.3.eng: They should live as though their head was on fire,
